Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 05:05PM CajunQueen wrote: I met with the gyno today.  She thinks we open ourselves up to more complications if we do the full hysterectomy and since I'm only a month and a half out from a nasty MRSA infected tissue expander that left me on IV antibiotics for 6 weeks - both she & the plastic surgeon feel more comfortable just doing the ooph right now.  And then I switch over from Tamoxifen to Arimidex, Aromasin & Afinitor... I think...  It's all just so much to learn & accept all at once!   MsTee, I'm so sorry to hear that you're losing your ovaries before having kids.  That must make all of this so much harder.  Hang in there & good luck with your treatments!
Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2014 07:46PM CajunQueen wrote: Surgery is in the morning! Eek!  I'm actually not too nervous.  I had a spinal bone biopsy yesterday that was scarier than any out patient surgery I can imagine.  The toughest part of surgery for me is typically finding a good vein for the IV.   Praying this procedure makes a big difference in my cancer and stops it in its tracks!! Amy

Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: CajunQueen wrote: Hi everyone,  we found 4 spots on my spine only days ago and are waiting on a biopsy.  My BC is Estrogen +.  I just recieved a call that my Dr. wants to talk about removing my ovaries ASAP.  Has anyone else removed theirs or heard of pros & cons.  I am PRE-mentapausal (just turned 38) and many of the medications I read that you are all on are for POST-menapausal patients.  I'm guessing this could be part of the reason.  And of course to stop estrogen production all together.  Are my ovaries the only place estrogen comes from? Any thoughts or experiences are greatly appreciated! Mets to Bones & Ovaries Dx 5/14/2013, ILC, Stage IIIC, Grade 1, 10/14 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Chemotherapy 5/31/2013 AC + T (Taxol) Surgery 9/20/2013 Lymph node removal: Left, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Radiation Therapy 11/14/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 2/19/2014 Dx 3/12/2014, ILC, Stage IV, mets Surgery 3/26/2014 Prophylactic ovary removal Hormonal Therapy 3/27/2014 Arimidex (anastrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 06:14PM CajunQueen wrote: Thanks!  It went well.  Worst part was finding a vein as I expected... They gave up after an hour & put it in my neck. :-( And since they didn't have the IV in early I didn't get the calm down drugs - so I had a near panic attack in the operating room.  Next time I may just tell them to use my neck after the first stick or two fail.    The incisions are super tiny!  One in my belly button and one on each side of my tummy (one is about an inch & the other about two inches).
Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2014 07:54PM CajunQueen wrote: It was out patient.  Got there around 8 am, surgery at 10 am, recovery from 11:30 - 2 pm.  I only had the ovaries, fallopian tubes and the small part of the uterus where the fallopian tubes go in removed.  Uterus stayed- so no- not a full hysterectomy.    I was told to take it very easy for a few days.  I took off today (the day after) and I wouldn't drive the day after.  But I am going to work from home tomorrow (in my bed) & drive a little.  No heavy lifting or exercising for 2-3 weeks.   I've been shuffling around the house a little and eating dinner at the table.  I'm not totally bed-ridden.  It's really not too bad.
Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 10:44AM CajunQueen wrote: yes, it was explained to me that fallopian tubes and a tiny bit of the uterus where the fallopian tubes enter will be removed as part of the procedure.  I'm not BRCA- she just said that's how it's done now... Amy

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2014 07:06AM CajunQueen wrote: Morning friends!  I'm becoming addicted to reading these boards! Lol Better use of my time than Facebook (which I can hardly stomach right now) or Candy Crush right now.  Funny thing is I have more work to do than ever, but I can't focus or concentrate on a task for more than 20 minutes without finding myself thinking about my recent news and what lies ahead and what that could truly "mean".  I've actually been quite strong (surprised myself!) but my drive has turned to educating myself on Stage 4 bone mets instead of my real job and taking care of the house, etc.  Don't get me wrong- no one is suffering.  The kids are fed and work projects get done... eventually... but my mind is somewhere else.  I'm eager to get past this phase.  I know it's the hardest part. My CT guided Biopsy (spine) is scheduled for Monday.  Bone scan next Thursday to check my legs just to be sure (PET CT was only to hips) the surgery to remove my ovaries will most likely be in the next week or two & then he mentioned three drugs I'd go on.  Not sure if it's an either/or situation or if I'd really be on all three: Arimidex, Aromasin & Afinitor. TarheelMichelle that was great information and I will certainly bring that up to the OBGYN! Thanks again for all the wonderful replies.  It's comforting to know the surgery should be easy too.
Posts.Title: 38, newly Stage IV, bone mets, Dr wants to remove ovaries ASAP CajunQueen KATE1974

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 07:22AM CajunQueen wrote: I agree Idunn, this site is like an online course on stage 4 cancer and I am soaking it all up! Kate, our treatment will be very similar.  I will start Arimidex after my surgery too.  Because I just recently had a bad tissue expander infection, they decided not to do a full hysterectomy to avoid further risk of complications.  And that's understandable.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2014 03:17PM CajunQueen wrote: Update:  Still recovering just fine, a little less tender every day.  Even a little itchy, which means it's healing.  But the update I wanted to add was that the light spotting I was having has turned into the worst period I have ever had in my life, complete with cramps, snippy attitude and fatigue.  By far the heaviest I've ever had too.  Only bright side is it's the last one I'll ever have!

Posts.Title: News about my cat scan so scared Connis Nel

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2014 01:41PM CajunQueen wrote: I was thinking of starting a very similar thread myself!  I was dx a year ago with stage IIIc ILC with 6 inflamed lymph nodes at diagnosis, had 6 months of AC & Taxol chemo, BXM and removed TEN possitive lymph nodes, then 36 rounds of radiation -only to discover it spread to my bones.  Decided to remove my ovaries to cut off the estrogen supply in hopes of stopping the bone mets from getting worse - and both ovaries came back possitive for ILC (but never showed on any scans).  Now I'm on Arimidex and preparing for reconstruction (we have to get these tissue expanders out, they keep getting infected - my body wants them out!).  My PS had me do a CT of my abdomin in preparation for the reconstruction and the write up from that test lists out the bone lessions (which I wasn't expecting to see) as well as the veins and such the PS was looking for.  Well it lists two additional lessions that were not on the bone scan last month!  I emailed my Oncologist and asked if these were new mets and he said "no, the CT just reads differently than the other scans" - but then he scheduled a bone scan for me in two weeks.  I'm just sick over this.  I can't catch a break.  Does this mean the Arimidex isn't working?  I've read that woman that don't respond well to their first AI often don't respond well to any of them.  I am 38 and have a 2 & 4 year old.  I feel like I can't get ahead of this sneaky disease and as possitive as I've been up until now - I am slowly loosing faith that we'll be able to get it under control.  Amy
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular Torridon MusicLover

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 03:17PM CajunQueen wrote: Thanks dbla! Torridon, the only thing that made that feeling go away for me was Zoloft.  I started at the lowest dose of 25 mg, but after mets diagnosis we pushed it up to 50.  That helps me keep functioning , work full-time, raise two toddlers...  Without it I'd cry every time someone asked how I was doing.   Now that I am on Zoloft, that feeling comes in waves.  I'll have a great morning, be super productive, maybe even happy- then I'll get an email that test results have posted or the pharmacy will call about one of my gazillion drugs, or a coworker will announce their retirement (which I 'll never live to see) and I snap back to terminal land and spend the next two hours trying to shake the sadness.   I imagine that once I find a treatment that really works for me and I get a long run of being stable those waves will be less often, but for now they are basically daily.  I try to allow myself a little time alone everyday (like right now) to check these boards or research a medicine or just be sad... But only a little while- I try very hard not to totally give in to the urge to just curl up and feel sorry for myself.  But again, the Zoloft reallllllllly helps! ~Amy

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2014 03:20PM CajunQueen wrote: Romansma, I understand what you mean about the rest of the family not "getting it" - but I have taken a little comfort in that.  At lease I'm not disrupting their lives too much.  But at the same time, I've had moments when my husband will ask me why I'm sad or depressed and I'm like, "really!?!?"  I don't want to be doom & gloom all the time, but I want them to respect my sense of urgency...
Posts.Title: Mothers with school aged children Kjones13 Kjones13

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2014 03:20AM CajunQueen wrote: Happy Birthday!  I know you can't help but wonder.  But spend it with people you love - doing something you love. It might make it easier to enjoy if you make it special for everyone?  Either way- your thought and emotions are valid!
Posts.Title: birthdays chris1959 susan_02143

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2014 02:23PM CajunQueen wrote: Today was tough for me.   First big holiday since stage 4 diagnosis. I spent most of the morning worrying that if I wasn't here the girls may not get cute, thoughtful Easter baskets, or have adorable matching dresses and bows to wear.  Then the thought of how many more Easters do I have with them entered my mind.  Then I became overwhelmed and wanted to just shut down - which would cause me to miss even more time with them - it's a nasty cycle!  I just so desperately don't want their lives affected and the truth is that their entire world will change in time - everything.  It's just been a hard, hard day so far.
Posts.Title: Mothers with school aged children Kjones13 Kjones13

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 10:21PM CajunQueen wrote: I agree, this gives us all hope!  Thanks for sharing & congratulations- you worked reallllllly hard for this moment!  Have a party this weekend & celebrate!
Posts.Title: Finally dating NED! lotusblossom aic

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2014 03:36PM CajunQueen wrote: Wow, Leftfootforward- you have your hands full with four young children!  A month long family trip sounds amazing!!!!!! Stella, sorry you're having a rough couple days.  Hang in there! We took the kids to a local jazz festival last night.  At first I was hesitant to get out, and my husband blew me off when I asked him to throw the stroller in the back... So it started off rough because there was carrying of tired 3 & 4 year olds and a lot of walking- but it actually ended up being really nice.  I just have to shake off the Debby Downer mood when I feel it coming on.  There is so much pressure to live life to the fullest, and make lasting memories, and be the person I want them to remember, and take lots of pictures...  All the pressure is just as exhausting as the pain and the treatments sometimes.  I'm a perfectionist and I know I do it to myself- but that's just how I feel. ~Amy
